Award.AwardTitle: Channel Properties Where Fluvial and Tidal Currents Meet
Award.AbstractNarration: This project will investigate how energy in tides is consumed as they advance tens to hundreds of kilometers upstream of the river mouth, and cause river currents to reverse. This work is novel and scientifically important because it provides a hydrodynamic framework for linking two parts of the river continuum, fluvial and estuarine channels, which heretofore had been treated separately. We will measure channel dimensions, sediment properties, velocity profiles, and turbulent stresses in river flows, and model the changes in energy as tides advance upstream. In the section of the river where flows transition from solely downstream flow to becoming influenced by tides, we hypothesize that tidal energy dissipation processes lead to enhanced riverbed erosion, giving rise to a characteristic river form. Findings from this study will help shed light on: 1) how to manage dam water releases to minimize erosion downstream, 2) the development and stability of river bed habitats, and 3) sediment discharge to the coastal zone. Moreover, this work will help characterize the effects of sea level rise on rivers far inland.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project investigates how the river continuum transitions between fully tidal and fully fluvial conditions.  In low gradient coastal plain landscapes river velocity, discharge and stage are influenced by terrestrial runoff processes in the upstream areas and by tidal fluctuations of sea level at the coast [Dalrymple and Choi, 2007]. Therefore, along the river continuum the channel flows and hydrodynamic processes transition from unidirectional downstream to bidirectional tidal [e.g., Goodin et al., 1999; Yankovsky et al., 2012].  For the more frequently occurring channel-forming fluvial and tidal discharges [sensu Leopold and Maddock, 1956] a dynamic tidal limit defines a transition reach or  the “fluvial-tidal transition zone” [Yankovsky et al., 2012]. Yankovsky et al. [2012] noted that an important attribute of the transition zone is that there are times during most tidal cycles when the upstream tidal and downstream fluvial currents have comparable speeds, and they produce comparable discharges.  Hence, these conditions give rise to hydrodynamic fluvial-tidal transition zone identified as a location along the river continuum with recurring dominance of ebb and flood conditions.  Further analyses show that the fluvial-tidal transition has five characteristic features. They are: a salinity transition, hydrodynamic transition, geomorphic transition, current reversal transition and a tidal transition.  We hypothesize that this set of features collectively move upstream or downstream with changes in sea level, and thus represent a type of indicator of sea level rise that may persist far upstream of the river mouth.
